The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: A COMBATE BETVVEEN SATAN tempting: And a CHRISTIAN triumphing: In the Comfort of the Creed.

sp.speaker: Satan.
sp.l: VVHY doeſt with hope (vild wretch) thy ſoule deceive?
Thou muſt be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Chriſtian.
sp.l: Not ſo, for I believe

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Yea ſo doe I: and yet I feele Hells Rod.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thou but beleev'ſt God is, I truſt in God

sp.speaker: Sa:
sp.l: What thou a ſinner truſt? thou temp'ſt him rather.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Who ſhould the poore Child truſt, if not the Father

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: The ſoule that ſins muſt dye, thy ſins are weighty.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yet God can pardon them, for he's Almighty,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: But he's of wicked men a juſt forſaker.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yet kinde to what he made, and he's my maker

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Why hath he made thee ſmart thus from thy birth?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: This is but love from th' Lord of Heaven and Earth.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Hark, God and Angels crie thou doeſt diſpleaſe us.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And yet in God's my comfort and in Jeſus

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: In ſin thou art born and bred, and do'ſt perſiſt.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: As ſin abounds in me, ſo grace in Chriſt

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Why ſpeak'ſt of grace, the Law makes thee undone?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nay then, why did God ſend his only Sonne

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Are not all ſinners of his Son abhord?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No, none that ſtrive to ſerve him as our Lord,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: But God can't die, of hope thou art bereav'd.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: But yet his manhood may which was conceived

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: How can man made of woman ſave the loſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes, being made perfect by the holy Ghoſt,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: But thou by nature art a wretch forlorne,

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: And yet to me in mercy a childe is borne

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: But thou art filthy and thy hart wants purging.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: His blood doth cleanſe me who came of the Virgin

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Preſumptuous men thus to tempt Chriſt, how dare ye?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: We tempt not Chriſt, we joy in Chriſt, with Mary,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Thou hop'ſt in vaine, from him ſin pulls thee aſunder.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Both ſin and ſinfull men, he ſuffered under

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: What ſuffer ſin, yet juſt? thy folly I ſmile at.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The ſin was mine; he juſt, ſaith Pontius Pilate,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: But yet the puniſhment of thy ſins abide.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No, for to quit them, he was crucifide,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Oh but the ſting of Death will wound thy head.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No, Chriſt puld out that ſting when he was dead

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Can he give life that lies himſelfe interd?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Yes, with him my ſins are hid and buried,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Thy poore and meane eſtate ſhews Chriſts offended.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Shall I thinke much to ſtoope when he deſcended

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Fear'ſt not Deaths wound, not in the grave to dwell?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Chriſt went, that I might not goe into Hell;

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: How cam'ſt thou free from ſting of death or paine?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: By Chriſt who on the third day roſe againt
And ſo captivity he captive led.
Riſing in glorious triumph from the dead,
Nor was my Saviours glory heerein ended,
But after he was riſen, he aſcended
To fit a place for me, and ſo hath given
Sure hope that I ſhall follow him into Heaven
Where now, in all my griefe and dumpiſh fits
He heares my prayers, there he reſts and ſits
Obſerve his Majeſty, he doth not ſtand
Inferiour like, but ſits at the right hand
Not of ſome earthly Prince, but his abode
Is in the high and heavenly houſe of God
Where as his only Sonne he rules; the rather
Can he make my requeſt knowne to the Father
That for his ſake my ſins which he found weighty,
May be forgiven by him which is Almighty,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: If th' art ſo ſure, then ſin, heres thy defence,
That Chriſt's in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Oh no he ſees from thence
And waites till wicked men fill up the ſum,
And meaſure of their ſins, then ſhall he come
Riding with thouſands Sain • s on clouds all ſpread
In flames of fire to judge the quick and dead;

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Then thou condemned ſhalt be: O feare and grieve.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Satan, I ſtill deny it, for I believe

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: In whom believeſt, that thus thou vants thy boaſt?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In Father, Sonne, and in the holy Ghoſt,
Who neere forſake nor leave in deſperate lurch
Thoſe who are of the holy Catholique Church
Let him but take me to himſlfe in union,
And give me with his peopl the Communion
I'm ſafe; for he to helpe then never faints,
Who keepe the bond of peace, and faith of Saints,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Thy wayes are crooked, and in them no eveneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In me's the ſin, in God is the forgiveneſſe
And heere my never ending • oy begins
To know that he's the pardoner of ſins,
Heel therofore take me to hi • high protection,
When the laſt trumpe ſhall ſound the reſurrection
Void ſin and Sathan both, my ſoule why load ye
With deſperate words? this • emple of the body,
Wherein corruption now a • d ſin is rife,
Shall come to parfect glory and the life
Not ſuch vaine earthly life which now is waſting:
But that bleſt life of Heaven thats everlaſting:
O Lord increaſe my faith, and grant that then
I may behold thy glorious face Amen.
Take but this ſhield of faith to arme your hearts,
So ſhall you quench all Satans fiery darts,
And though your nature doe in name betray,
This faith ſhall make your honours laſt for ay.
